newsitem.title: USA: Louisiana GO upgrade could cut costs by $1.5 mln.
newsitem.headline: Louisiana GO upgrade could cut costs by $1.5 mln.

text.p: Louisiana could save up to $1.5 million in interest costs on next week's $225.625 million general obligation bond sale as a result of improved ratings, state Treausurer Ken Duncan said.
The sale is set for March 19 via competitive bid.
On Thursday, Moody's Investors Service raised Louisiana's GO bond rating to A3 from Baa1 and Fitch Investors Service gave the state's GO bonds a first-time rating of single-A.
Louisiana is still waiting to hear from Standard & Poor's Corp, which cut Louisiana GOs from single-A to A-minus in 1995 and has the A-minus rating on CreditWatch with negative implications.
Duncan said S&P had requested additional information on the state's Medicaid budget "and is therefore taking somewhat longer to reach its rating decision" on the upcoming issue.
It was the first time since 1987 that all three rating agencies have had Louisiana GOs in the single-A category. But Louisiana is still the lowest-rated state in the nation.

"Louisiana's credit outlook is clearly moving in the right direction and the state has made progress in getting its fiscal house in order," Duncan said in a prepared statement. "We must continue to live within our means, spend the resources we have wisely and put money away for a rainy day." He said Louisiana also needs to fully resolve chronic shortfalls in its Medicaid budget and make permanent its temporary sales taxes on food and utilities.
